Jim, everybody,
The mounting is strange, the fittings are very old, the kurikata and fuchi
are made of thin metal with the nanako almost worn away, the inlay looks
like uttori with a 'trench' around each piece but the gold is not worn as I
would expect, you can easily tell uttori when you can see the gaps in the
gold inlay, this inlay is perfect. One thought I have is that the kashira
was originally the kojiri, I feel the shape would make more sense this way.
Altogether a puzzling item. There is no bare wood visible.
Regarding another tsuba, if you have Sotheby's London catalogue of 11
November lot 27 is a Soten tsuba with a Hozon paper, the item is clearly
19th century and a long time after the 2nd Soten, any ideas?
Alan



----- Original Message -----
From: "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, November 13, 2003 12:56 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: anyone for a piece at auction


: Ray,
: I think that it's a legitimate Japanese koshirae, although the bare wood
parts are apparently replacements to fill in the "blanks."  It'd be hard to
cobble together something with such an unusual shape to the saya, tsuka and
kashira.  The shape and the suspension ring remind me of toppei koshirae
from Bakumatsu.  The catalog entry claims that the fittings are decorated in
uttori, which if correct would suggest a much earlier date.  I can't tell
from the photo whether the ring might be a later modification.  Without
having seen it in person all I can do is speculate.  It's unusual enough
that even after seeing it I wouldn't be surprised if I was still stuck.
:
: Alan (or anyone else who might have seen it (or now owns it)), any ideas?
This is the lot illustrated as 253, but described under 251.
:
: Jim
:
:
:
:   Hi Jim, thanks for the background. If not Ainu, I am very curious
:   what the origin of a koshirae like this would be. Perhaps someone
:   simply cobbled this together from the fragments of other koshirae?
:   Or, maybe this piece originated outside of Japan. I am sure it would
:   be instructive to see the blade...
:
:   - Ray
:
